section.title: Rate of Accumulation and the Derivative

subsection.title: Overview
subsection.p: We have learned that functions defined as accumulation functions, f(x) = f_0 + \int_{x_0}^x f'(z) \, dz, can be described in terms of monotonicity and concavity in terms of the signs and monotonicity of the rate of accumulation f'(x). Of course, most functions are not written with an accumulation formula representation. This raises a central question of calculus: Which functions can be expressed as an accumulation? And if a function can be expressed as an accumulation, how do we find the formula for the rate of accumulation that will be the integrand in that representation?

At present, we have formulas relating the rate of accumulation and the accumulation function only for simple polynomials. (See .) In this section, we will discuss how to use those elementary accumulation rates and functions to compute the rate of accumulation for simple polynomials. We will also illustrate some additional examples of describing the monotonicity and concavity of a function in terms the corresponding rate function.

Looking forward, we will need new tools to find the rate function for more complicated functions. To do this, we will be introducing a new concept called the instantaneous rate of change or derivative at a point. This notion of a derivative is defined in terms of a limit. The properties of limits will allow us to develop properties of derivatives. These properties will allow us to create differentiation rules to compute derivative functions that will characterize the instantaneous rate of change of a function at any point where the derivative is defined.

At that stage of development, we will have two notions of rate of changethe rate of accumulation and the derivative. These are, in fact, the same thing, which we will establish as the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. Because the rate of accumulation and derivative are different interpretations of the same thing, we will use the language of derivatives now even though in context, we are thinking in terms of the integrand of an accumulation function.

subsection.title: The Rate of Accumulation
subsection.p: When a function is defined as an accumulation function in terms of a definite integral, it is easy enough to determine the rate of accumulation or derivative by identifying the function in the integrand.

statement.p: If f(x) is defined as \displaystyle f(x) = 3 + \int_1^{x} z^2-5z \, dz, then the integrand z^2-5z must be f'(z). Changing variables means f'(x) = x^2-5x.

subsection.p: The linearity properties of definite integrals imply that rates of accumulation also satisfy linearity properties. Thus, we can think of polynomials as sums of elementary components whose derivatives are known.

statement.p: If f(x) has a rate of accumulation f'(x) and g(x) has a rate of accumulation g'(x), then the function h(x)=c_1 f(x) + c_2 g(x) with constants c_1 and c_2 has a rate of accumulation h'(x) = c_1 f'(x) + c_2 g'(x).

proof.p:
Using a common initial point at x=a, we can write
f(x) = f(a) + \int_a^x f'(z) \, dz, g(x) = g(a) + \int_a^x g'(z) \, dz.
Because h(x) = c_1 f(x) + c_2 g(x), we can use the linearity properties of definite integrals to rewrite
h(x) &= c_1 \Big(f(a) + \int_a^x f'(z) \, dz\Big) + c_2 \Big(g(a) + \int_a^x g'(z) \, dz\Big) &= c_1 f(a) + c_2 g(a) + c_1 \int_a^x f'(z) \, dz + c_2 \int_a^x g'(z) \, dz &= (c_1 f(a) + c_2 g(a)) + \int_a^x (c_1 f'(z) + c_2 g'(z)) \, dz
Since h(a) = c_1 f(a) + c_2 g(a), we can see that h(x) has been written in the form of an accumulation with a rate of accumulation h'(x) = c_1 f'(x) + c_2 g'(x).

subsection.p: The elementary accumulation formulas for simple powers can be interpreted as complementary rules to find the rate of accumulation for simple powers. As an example, consider the known accumulation formula \int_0^x z^2 \, dz = \frac{1}{3}x^3. If we multiply both sides of the equation by 3</> to clear the fraction and move the constant inside the integral, we have an equivalent statement x^3 = \int_0^x 3z^2 \, dz. That is, we have just found that if f(x)=x^3 then f'(x)=3x^2. Each accumulation formula allows us to identify a corresponding rate of accumulation for simple powers.

theorem.title: The Power Rule for the Rate of Accumulation

statement.p:
The elementary accumulation formulas lead to the following elementary rates of accumulation for powers of the independent variable.
If f(x) = x, then f'(x)=1.
If f(x) = x^2, then f'(x)=2x.
If f(x) = x^3, then f'(x)=3x^2.
If f(x) = x^4, then f'(x)=4x^3.

proof.p: Each formula follows by applying the same technique described above for f(x)=x^3 on the corresponding accumulation formula.

subsection.p: You might have noticed a pattern in these formulas, that the rate of accumulation involves a power that has been reduced by one from the accumulation function and that the power for the accumulation has become a constant multiple. Without creating more accumulation formulas, we can not prove that this pattern will always be true. In mathematics, we call a pattern that we believe might be true a conjecture.

conjecture.title: Power Rule for Rate of Accumulation

statement.p: For any constant power n, the function f(x) = x^n has a rate of accumulation f'(x) = n x^{n-1}.

subsection.p: This conjecture happens to be true, but we will need to wait to develop the process of differentiation to prove it. We will need one more simple rate of accumulation to deal with constant terms. A constant function sees no change, so the accumulation must always be zero, and that will come from a rate of accumulation that is zero.

statement.p: If f(x) = c for some constant c (a constant function), then f'(x)=0.

proof.p: Because \displaystyle \int_a^b 0 \, dx = 0, we can write f(x) = c + \int_{a}^{x} 0 \, dz for any value a. Thus, the rate of accumulation f'(x) = 0.

subsection.p: With these building blocks now in place and the linearity properties available to put them together, we are ready to find the rate of accumulation (the derivative) for simple polynomials.

solution.p: We look at f(x) as a sum of three terms: f_1(x)=x^2, f_2(x)=-6x, and f_3(x)=5. First, f_1(x)=x^2 is an elementary power for which we know f_1'(x)=2x. Next, f_2(x)=-6x is a constant -6 times x, so f_2'(x) is the same constant times 1, f_2'(x)=-6\cdot 1 = -6. Finally, f_3(x)=5 is a constant function so that f_3'(x)=0. The linearity for rates of accumulation implies f'(x)=2x-6+0 = 2x-6.

subsection.title: Using the Rate of Accumulation
subsection.p: Now that we know how to find the rate of accumulation for simple polynomials, we can express a polynomial as an accumulation with that rate.

statement.p: Express f(x)=x^3 + 6x^2 - 4 as an accumulation from x=1.

solution.p:
Start by finding the rate of accumulation. f'(x)=3x^2 + 6(2x) + 0 = 3x^2 + 12x The rate of accumulation becomes the integrand of the accumulation. Because the integral will start at x=1, the initial value will be f(1) = 1^3 + 6 \cdot 1^2 - 4 = 3. We can now write f(x) as an accumulation from x=1:
f(x) &= f(1) + \int_1^x f'(z) \, dz &= 3 + \int_1^x 3z^2 + 12z \, dz.
